text: Which of the following is not an advantage of a partnership over a corporation?

choices.text: Ease of formation
Unlimited liability
Less governmental regulations
All of the above

explanation: Unlimited liability is actually a disadvantage of partnerships, not an advantage. The other options (ease of formation and less governmental regulations) are advantages of partnerships over corporations.

text: For financial accounting purposes, assets of an individual partner contributed to a partnership are recorded by the partnership at

choices.text: Historical cost
Book value
Fair market value
Lower of cost or market

explanation: When a partner contributes assets to a partnership, these assets should be recorded at their fair market value at the time of contribution, as this represents the true economic value being brought into the partnership.

text: On July 1, X and Y formed a partnership. X contributed cash. Y, previously a sole proprietor, contributed property other than cash, including realty subject to a mortgage, which the partnership assumed. Y's capital account on July 1, should be recorded at

choices.text: Y's capital account on July 1, should be recorded at
Y's book value of the property on July 1
Y's book value of the property less the mortgage payable on July 1
The fair value of the property less the mortgage payable on July 1

explanation: When a partner contributes property subject to a mortgage, the capital account should be credited with the fair value of the property less the mortgage assumed by the partnership.

text: Mr. A and Mr. B agreed to form a partnership. The fair values of the partners' net contribution vary however, the partners agreed to have equal capital credits. Cash settlement shall be made between them for the difference. Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: The asset contributions of the partners shall be debited to equal amounts
The cash settlement between the partners will either increase or decrease the total partnership capital
The cash settlement between the partners will not be recorded in the partnership books
Mr. A shall pay Mr. B to have their capital balances equal

explanation: Cash settlements between partners for equalizing capital contributions are personal transactions and should not be recorded in the partnership books.

text: How should the partners in a business partnership share in the profits or losses of the partnership?

choices.text: Equally
At whatever basis of allocation that the dominating partner deems reasonable
In accordance with the partnership agreement
None of the above

explanation: The sharing of profits and losses should be based on the partnership agreement, which is the legal document governing the partnership's operations.

text: According to the Philippine Civil Code, if only the share of each partner in the profits has been agreed upon, the share of each in the losses shall be

choices.text: In equal amounts
In equal amounts, but excluding the industrial partner
In proportion to the partners' contributions
The same as the sharing in profits

explanation: Under the Philippine Civil Code, when only profit sharing is specified, the loss sharing follows the same ratio as profit sharing.

text: According to the Philippine Civil Code, in the absence of a stipulation on the sharing of profits or losses, partnership profits and losses shall be shared by the partners

choices.text: Equally
In accordance with the partnership agreement
In proportion to what the partners may have contributed
In proportion to what the partners may have contributed, but the industrial partner shall not be liable for the losses

explanation: In the absence of any agreement, the Philippine Civil Code provides that profits and losses shall be shared equally among partners.

text: Partners active in a partnership business should have their share of partnership profits based on the following

choices.text: A combination of salaries plus interest based on average capital balances
A combination of salaries and percentage of net income after salaries and any other allocation basis
Salaries only
Percentage of net income after salaries is paid to inactive partners

explanation: Active partners typically receive a combination of salary and a percentage of remaining profits after all allocations, which recognizes both their service and investment in the partnership.

text: Which of the following best describes the use of interest on invested capital as a means of allocating profits?

choices.text: If interest on invested capital is used, it must be used for all partners
Interest is allocated only if there is partnership net profit
Invested capital balances are never affected by drawings of the partnerships
Use of beginning or ending measures of invested capital may be subject to manipulation that distorts the measure of invested capital

explanation: Using only beginning or ending capital balances can be manipulated by partners through strategic timing of contributions or withdrawals, making it an imperfect measure for profit allocation.

text: A partnership agreement calls for allocation of profits and losses by salary allocations, a bonus allocation, interest on capital, with any remainder to be allocated by preset ratios. If a partnership has a loss to allocate, generally which of the following procedures would be applied?

choices.text: Any loss would be allocated equally to all partners
Any salary allocation criteria would not be used
The bonus criteria would not be used
The loss would be allocated using the profit and loss ratios, only

explanation: When there is a loss, it is typically allocated using the profit and loss ratios only, as salary allocations and bonuses are not appropriate for loss allocation.

text: Which of the following statements is true concerning the treatment of salaries in partnership accounting?

choices.text: Partner salaries may be used to allocate profits and losses they are not considered expenses of the partnership
Partner salaries are equal to the annual partner draw
The salary of a partner is treated in the same manner as salaries of corporate employees
Partner salaries are directly closed to the capital account

explanation: Partner salaries are not actual expenses but rather a method of profit allocation, and they are not treated the same as employee salaries.

text: Partnership drawings are

choices.text: Always maintained in a separate account from the partners' capital account
Equal to partners' salaries
Usually maintained in a separate draw account with any excess draws being debited directly to the capital account
Not discussed in the specific contract provisions of the partnership

explanation: Partnership drawings are typically tracked in a separate account, and any excess draws are charged against the partner's capital account.

text: When a new partner is admitted into a partnership and the capital of the old partners decreases, which of the following explains the reason for the decrease? I. Undervalued liabilities were written up to their fair values. II. Undervalued assets were written up to their fair values.

choices.text: I only
II only
Both I and II
Neither I nor II

explanation: Both writing up undervalued liabilities and assets to their fair values can result in a decrease in the old partners' capital accounts.

text: Under the bonus method, any increase or decrease in the capital credit of a partner is

choices.text: Deducted from or added to the capital credits of the other partners
Recognized as goodwill
Recognized as expense
Deferred and amortized to profit or loss

explanation: Under the bonus method, any adjustment to a partner's capital credit is offset by corresponding adjustments to the other partners' capital accounts.

text: The admission of a new partner effected through purchase of interest from an existing partners is

choices.text: Recorded in the partnership's books as a debit to cash or other asset and credit to the incoming partner's capital account
Recorded in the partnership's books as a transfer within equity
Recorded in the partnership's books as a transfer from equity to liability
Not recorded in its entirety

explanation: When a new partner purchases an interest from existing partners, it is recorded as a transfer within equity, as it only affects the capital accounts.

text: In XY Partnership, X and Y had a capital ratio of 3:1 and a profit and loss ratio of 2:1, respectively. The bonus method was used to record Z's admittance as a new partner. What ratio would be used to allocate, to X and Y, the excess of Z's contributions over the amount credited to Z's capital account?

choices.text: X and Y's new relative capital ratio
X and Y's new relative capital profit and loss ratio
X and Y's old capital ratio
X and Y's old profit and loss ratio

explanation: When using the bonus method, any excess or deficiency is allocated to the existing partners using their old profit and loss ratio.

text: When partner X retired, the partnership paid X an amount that was lower than the balance of his capital account. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: The partnership assets decreased as a result of the retirement
The other partners' capital balances increased
The partnership assets were not affected
The number of capital accounts in the partnership chart of accounts decreased

explanation: When a partner retires and receives a payment, the partnership assets are affected as cash or other assets are used to make the payment.

text: A bonus is recognized by existing partners at the date a new partner joins a partnership when which of the following relationships occur?

choices.text: The new partner's contribution exceeds his/her percentage of total partnership capital after the investment is made
The new partner's contribution is less than his/her percentage of total partnership capital after the investment is made
The new partner's contribution is equal to his/her percentage of total partnership capital after the investment is made
It is not possible to determine the answer to this question

explanation: A bonus to existing partners occurs when the new partner's contribution is less than the capital credit given, with the difference being allocated to the existing partners.

text: Which of the following statements is true with regard to a withdrawing partner?

choices.text: A bonus must be paid to the retiring partner
A bonus may be paid to the retiring partner
A bonus must be paid to the retiring partner or to the remaining partners
Recognizing a bonus is not appropriate when a partner retires

explanation: A bonus to the retiring partner is optional and depends on the terms of the partnership agreement and the circumstances of the retirement.

text: A simple partnership liquidation requires

choices.text: Periodic payments to creditors and partners determined by a safe payments schedule
Partnership assets to be converted into cash with full payment made to all outside creditors before remaining cash is distributed to partners in a lump sum payment
Only creditors to be paid in an orderly manner
Periodic payments to partners as cash becomes available

explanation: In a simple liquidation, all assets are converted to cash, creditors are paid in full, and then remaining cash is distributed to partners.

text: The following is the priority sequence in which liquidation proceeds will be distributed for a partnership

choices.text: Partnership drawings, partnership liabilities, partnership loans, partnership capital balances
Partnership liabilities, partnership loans, partnership capital balances
Partnership liabilities, partnership loans, partnership drawings, partnership capital balances
Partnership liabilities, partnership capital balances, partnership loans

explanation: The correct order of distribution is: first to outside creditors (liabilities), then to partners' loans, and finally to partners' capital balances.

text: What is the nature of liability of general partners as to partnership debts or obligations?

choices.text: They are liable equally up to the extent of their separate assets after the partnership assets are exhausted
They are liable pro-rata up to the extent of their separate assets after the partnership assets are exhausted
They are liable pro-rata up to the extent of their capital contribution only
They are liable solidarily up to the extent of their separate assets after the partnership assets are exhausted

explanation: General partners have solidary (joint and several) liability, meaning each partner can be held liable for the full amount of partnership debts after partnership assets are exhausted.

text: X and Y are partners of XY Partnership which is undergoing liquidation. After XY Partnership's assets were realized and its liabilities settled, X's capital account has a negative balance. Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: Y shall absorb X's capital deficiency if X is solvent
X shall make an additional contribution if X is insolvent
X and Y shall make pro rata contributions to eliminate X's capital deficiency
Y shall absorb X's capital deficiency if X is insolvent

explanation: If a partner with a capital deficiency is insolvent, the remaining partners must absorb the deficiency in their profit and loss ratio.

text: If a partner with a debit capital balance during liquidation is personally solvent, the

choices.text: Partner must invest additional assets in the partnership
Partner's debit balance will be allocated to the other partners
Other partners will give the partner enough cash to absorb the debit balance
Partnership will loan the partner enough cash to absorb the debit balance

explanation: If a partner has a debit capital balance and is solvent, they must contribute additional assets to the partnership to cover their deficiency.

text: In accounting for liquidation of partnership, cash payments to partners after all non-partner creditors' claims have been satisfied, but before the final cash distribution, should be according to

choices.text: The partners' relative profit and loss sharing ratios
The final balances in partner capital accounts
The partners' relative share of the gain or loss on liquidations
Safe payments computations

explanation: Safe payments computations are used to determine how much can be safely distributed to partners before all assets are liquidated, ensuring no partner receives more than their eventual share.

text: If a partnership has only non-cash assets, all liabilities have been properly disbursed, and no additional liquidation expenses are expected, the maximum potential loss to the partnership in the liquidation process is

choices.text: The fair market value of the non-cash assets
The book value of the non-cash assets
The estimated proceeds from the sale of the assets less the book value of the non-cash assets
None of the above

explanation: The maximum potential loss is the book value of the non-cash assets, as this represents the amount that could be lost if the assets were sold for nothing.

text: In partnership liquidation, the last remaining cash distribution should be made according to the ratio of

choices.text: The individual partners' profit and loss agreement
The individual partners' capital accounts, increased by partner loans to the partnership
The individual partners' capital accounts, increased by partnership loans to the partners and decreased by partner loans to the partnership
The individual partners' capital accounts, decreased by partnership loans to the partners and increased by partner loans to the partnership

explanation: The final distribution should consider both the capital accounts and any loans between partners and the partnership, with partnership loans to partners increasing the distribution and partner loans to the partnership decreasing it.

text: If all partners are included in the first installment of an installment liquidation, then in future installments

choices.text: Cash will be distribution according to the residual profit and loss sharing ratio
Cash should not be distributed until all non-cash assets are converted into cash
A safe payments schedule must be prepared before each cash distribution to avoid excessive payments to partners
A cash distribution plan must be prepared so that partners will know when they will be included in cash distributions

explanation: Safe payments schedules are necessary for each distribution to ensure partners don't receive more than their eventual share of the partnership assets.

text: Which partner is considered the most vulnerable as a result of a computation of vulnerability rankings?

choices.text: The partner with the lowest vulnerability ranking, who also has the lowest loss absorption potential
The partner with the lowest vulnerability ranking, who also has the highest loss absorption potential
The partner with the highest vulnerability ratio, who also has the lowest loss absorption potential
The partner with the highest vulnerability ranking, who also has the highest loss absorption potential

explanation: The most vulnerable partner is the one with the highest vulnerability ratio and lowest loss absorption potential, as they are most likely to receive less than their capital balance in liquidation.

text: A partner's maximum loss absorbable is calculated by

choices.text: Dividing the partner's capital balance by his or her profit-and-loss-sharing percentage
Multiplying the partner's capital balance by his or her profit-and-loss-sharing percentage
Multiplying distributable assets by the partner's profit-sharing percentage
Dividing the partner's capital balance by his or her percentage interest in capital

explanation: Maximum loss absorbable is calculated by dividing the partner's capital balance by their profit-and-loss-sharing percentage, which shows how much loss the partner can absorb before their capital is eliminated.

text: In a Statement of Financial Affairs, a company's assets should be valued at

choices.text: Historical cost
Net realizable value, if lower than historical cost
Replacement cost
Net realizable value, whether higher or lower than historical cost

explanation: In a Statement of Financial Affairs, assets are valued at their net realizable value regardless of whether it's higher or lower than historical cost, as this represents the amount that could be realized from their sale.

text: In a Statement of Financial Affairs, a company's liabilities should be valued at

choices.text: The present value of future cash flows
Net realizable value
The amount required for settlement
Replacement cost

explanation: Liabilities in a Statement of Financial Affairs should be valued at the amount required for settlement, as this represents the actual amount that will need to be paid to satisfy the obligations.

text: In a Statement of Financial Affairs, a specific liability may be classified as

choices.text: Current or long-term
Secured or unsecured
Monetary or nonmonetary
Direct or indirect

explanation: In a Statement of Financial Affairs, liabilities are primarily classified as secured or unsecured, as this classification is crucial for determining the order of payment in liquidation.

text: A Statement of Financial Affairs of a corporation in financial difficulty indicates that unsecured creditors would receive a percentage of their claims. Which one of the following assets is most likely to realize the smallest percentage of its book value?

choices.text: Accounts receivable
Inventories
Plant and equipment
Goodwill

explanation: Goodwill is most likely to realize the smallest percentage of its book value because it has no physical substance and its value is highly dependent on the going concern value of the business, which is typically minimal in liquidation.

text: The estimated deficiency to unsecured creditors without priority is computed as

choices.text: Net free assets less total unsecured liabilities without priority
Net free assets divided by total unsecured liabilities without priority
Total assets at realizable values less total liabilities at expected net settlement amounts
A or C

explanation: The estimated deficiency can be computed either as net free assets less total unsecured liabilities without priority, or as total assets at realizable values less total liabilities at expected net settlement amounts.

text: In a Statement of Affairs

choices.text: Assets pledged with partially secured creditors are shown on the asset side of the statement and as a deduction on the liability side of the statement
Assets pledged with fully secured creditors are shown only on the liability side of the statement
Liabilities owed to fully secured creditors are shown only on the asset side of the statement
Liabilities owed to partially secured creditors are shown on the asset side of the balance sheet and as a deduction on the liability side of the statement

explanation: In a Statement of Affairs, assets pledged with partially secured creditors are shown on both sides of the statement to properly reflect their dual role in the liquidation process.

text: The recovery percentage is calculated by which of the following formulas?

choices.text: Estimated amount available for unsecured creditors with/without priority divided by total claims of unsecured creditors with/without priority
Estimated realizable value of all debtor assets divided by book value of debtor assets
Estimated gain/loss on liquidation divided by total estimated net realizable value of debtor assets
Net estimated proceeds available to unsecured creditors divided by total claims of unsecured creditors

explanation: The recovery percentage is calculated by dividing the net estimated proceeds available to unsecured creditors by their total claims, which shows what percentage of their claims they can expect to recover.

text: A corporation's Statement of Affairs shows a recovery percentage of 115. This means

choices.text: Secured creditors will receive an amount in excess of the book value of their claims
Unsecured creditors will receive an amount in excess of the book value of their claims
Stockholders may expect some return on their interests
An error was made in the preparation of the statement

explanation: A recovery percentage of 115% means unsecured creditors will receive 115% of their claims, indicating they will receive more than the book value of their claims.

text: What are free assets?

choices.text: Assets for which net realizable value is greater than historical cost
Assets for which no market exists
Assets for which replacement cost is greater than historical cost
Assets available to be distributed for liabilities with priority and other unsecured obligations

explanation: Free assets are those that are not pledged as security for any liabilities and are available for distribution to satisfy claims of creditors with priority and other unsecured obligations.

text: All of the following items are liabilities with priority except

choices.text: Obligations arising between the date an order of relief is issued and the date of final realization of assets
Employee claims for contributions to benefit plans earned more than 180 days preceding the filing of a petition
Government claims for unpaid taxes
Claims for the return of deposits made by customers to acquire property or services, which were never delivered or provided by the debtor

explanation: Employee claims for contributions to benefit plans earned more than 180 days before the filing of a petition are not considered priority claims, as they fall outside the priority period.

text: The Investment in Branch and Home Office accounts are best described as

choices.text: Contra accounts
Adjunct accounts
Reciprocal accounts
Investment accounts

explanation: The Investment in Branch and Home Office accounts are reciprocal accounts because they represent the same relationship from different perspectives - the home office's investment in the branch and the branch's obligation to the home office.

text: The Home Office ledger account in the accounting records of a branch is best compared to

choices.text: An equity account
A revenue account
A liability account
A deferred revenue account

explanation: The Home Office account in the branch's books is similar to an equity account because it represents the branch's net investment in the home office, similar to how equity represents ownership interest.

text: For external reporting, the individual financial statements of the home office and branch are combined

choices.text: By using complex consolidation procedures
By recognizing the home office's own assets, liabilities, income and expenses plus its share in the branch's assets, liabilities, income and expenses
By adding together similar items of assets, liabilities, income and expenses
By adding together similar items of assets, liabilities, income and expenses and eliminating reciprocal accounts

explanation: When combining financial statements, similar items are added together while reciprocal accounts (like Investment in Branch and Home Office) are eliminated to avoid double counting.

text: In preparing the combined financial statements of the home office and its various branches

choices.text: Both reciprocal and non-reciprocal accounts are combined
Both reciprocal and non-reciprocal accounts are eliminated
Reciprocal accounts are eliminated but non-reciprocal accounts are combined
Reciprocal accounts are combined but non-reciprocal accounts are eliminated

explanation: In combined financial statements, reciprocal accounts are eliminated to avoid double counting, while non-reciprocal accounts are combined to show the total financial position of the entire organization.

text: Which of the following accounts would be shown in the combined financial statements of the home office and branch

choices.text: Investment in branch account
Allowance for unrealized gross margin in branch inventory
Home office account
None of the above

explanation: None of these accounts would appear in the combined financial statements because they are all reciprocal accounts that are eliminated in the combination process.

text: The main difference between the net income reported in the separate income statement of the branch and the net income reported by the home office for the branch's operation is the

choices.text: Overstatement of beginning and ending inventory reported by the branch
Overstatement of total goods available for sale reported by the branch
Overstatement of costs of goods sold reported by the branch
Overstatement of shipment from home office reported by the branch

explanation: The branch's income statement typically overstates cost of goods sold because it includes the transfer price markup from the home office, while the home office's records for the branch reflect the actual cost.

text: Which represents the proper journal entry for a periodic inventory system that should be made on the books of the home office when goods that cost the home office P100,000 to manufacture are shipped to a branch at a transfer price of P125,000 and the billed price is not recorded in the shipments to branch account?

choices.text: Investment in Branch Shipments to branch P100,000 P100,000
Investment in Branch Shipments to branch P125,000 P125,000
Investment in Branch Shipments to branch Unrealized profit P125,000 P100,000 25,000
Shipment to branch Unrealized profit Shipments from home office P100,000 25,000 P125,000

explanation: This entry properly records the transfer of goods at cost (P100,000) to the shipments account, recognizes the markup (P25,000) as unrealized profit, and debits the investment in branch account for the total transfer price (P125,000).

text: Which of the following statements is/are true regarding sales agency and branch? I. A sales agency is not a self-contained business but rather acts only on behalf of the home office II. A branch is a self-contained business which acts independently, but within the bounds of the company policy and subject to the control of the home office

choices.text: I only
II only
I and II
Neither I nor II

explanation: Both statements are true. A sales agency is an extension of the home office that acts on its behalf, while a branch is a more independent unit that maintains its own accounting records but operates under home office control.

text: The two basic types of cost accounting systems are

choices.text: Job order and job accumulation systems
Job order and process cost systems
Process cost and batch systems
Job order and batch systems

explanation: Job order and process cost systems are the two fundamental types of cost accounting systems, with job order used for unique products and process costing used for mass-produced identical items.

text: Two basic costing systems for assigning costs to products or services are job order and process costing. These two costing systems are usually viewed as being on opposite ends of a spectrum. The fundamental criterion employed to determine whether job costing or process costing should be employed is

choices.text: Proportion of direct traceable costs expended to produce the product or service
Number of cost pools employed to allocate the indirect costs to the product or service
Type of bases used in allocating the indirect cost pools to the product or service
The nature and amount of the product or service brought to the marketplace for customer consumption

explanation: The choice between job order and process costing depends primarily on the nature of the product or service and the production process, not on cost allocation methods or cost pools.

text: Job order costing and process costing have which of the following characteristics? Job Order Costing Process Costing

choices.text: Homogeneous products Heterogeneous products and large quantities and small quantities
Homogeneous products Heterogeneous products and small quantities and large quantities
Heterogeneous products Homogeneous products and large quantities and small quantities
Heterogeneous products Homogeneous products and small quantities and large quantities

explanation: Job order costing is used for heterogeneous products produced in small quantities, while process costing is used for homogeneous products produced in large quantities.

text: Which of the following would be accounted for using a job order cost system?

choices.text: The production of personal computers
The production of automobiles
The refining of petroleum
The construction of a new campus building

explanation: Job order costing is most appropriate for unique, custom projects like building construction, while the other options involve mass production of identical items which would use process costing.

text: In a job cost system, the application of factory overhead is usually reflected in the general ledger as an increase in

choices.text: Factory overhead control
Finished goods control
Work in process control
Cost of goods sold

explanation: When factory overhead is applied in a job cost system, it is debited to Work in Process Control as it represents costs being added to the production process.

text: When a job is completed and all costs have been accumulated on a job cost sheet, the journal entry that should be made is

choices.text: Finished Goods Inventory Direct Materials Direct Labor Manufacturing Overhead
Work In Process Inventory Direct Materials Direct Labor Manufacturing Overhead
Raw Materials Inventory Work in Process Inventory
Finished Goods Inventory Work in Process Inventory

explanation: When a job is completed, the costs are transferred from Work in Process Inventory to Finished Goods Inventory, as the product is now complete and ready for sale.

text: Spoiled units are

choices.text: Units that cannot be economically reworked to bring them up to standard
Units that can be economically reworked to bring them up to standard
The same as defective units
Considered abnormal losses

explanation: Spoiled units are those that cannot be economically reworked to meet quality standards, unlike defective units which can be reworked.

text: Normal spoilage is defined as unacceptable production that

choices.text: Arises because of a special job or process
Occurs in on-going operations
Is caused specifically by human error
Is in excess of that which is expected

explanation: Normal spoilage is the expected, unavoidable waste that occurs during normal production operations, as opposed to abnormal spoilage which is unexpected or avoidable.

text: Abnormal spoilage is

choices.text: Spoilage that is forecasted or planned
Spoilage that is in excess of planned
Accounted for as a product cost
Debited to Cost of Goods Sold

explanation: Abnormal spoilage is waste that exceeds the expected or normal level of spoilage and is typically treated as a period cost rather than a product cost.

text: Which of the following statements concerning spoilage in a job-order costing is correct?

choices.text: The cost of abnormal spoilage is recorded as period cost or expense

When normal spoilage occurs because of the specification of a particular job, cost of normal loss shall be capitalized to that specific job reduced by the current disposal value/net realizable value of the spoiled units
When normal spoilage is a characteristic of a given production cycle, the cost of normal loss is not charged to a specific job but will be closed to manufacturing overhead control account
All of the above

explanation: All statements are correct regarding the treatment of spoilage in job-order costing, including the treatment of abnormal spoilage as a period cost and the different ways normal spoilage can be accounted for depending on the circumstances.

text: Which of the following statements concerning rework costs in a job-order costing is correct?

choices.text: If the normal rework cost is attributable to a specific job, it shall be capitalized to that particular job
If the normal rework cost is common to all jobs, it shall be debited to manufacturing overhead control account
If the rework cost is abnormal, it shall be recorded as a period cost or expense
All of the above

explanation: All statements are correct regarding the treatment of rework costs in job-order costing, including the capitalization of job-specific rework costs and the treatment of abnormal rework as a period cost.

text: When the amount of overapplied factory overhead is significant, the entry to close overapplied factory overhead will most likely require

choices.text: A debit to cost of goods sold
Debits to cost of goods sold, finished goods inventory, and work in process inventory
A credit to cost of goods sold
Credits to cost of goods sold, finished goods inventory and work in process inventory

explanation: When overapplied overhead is significant, it should be allocated proportionally to all accounts that contain overhead costs, which includes work in process, finished goods, and cost of goods sold.

text: What is the best cost accumulation procedure to use when a single product is manufactured in a continuous process?

choices.text: Process
Job order
Standard
Actual

explanation: Process costing is the most appropriate method for continuous production of a single product, as it allows for the accumulation of costs across production departments over time.

text: Process costing is used in companies that

choices.text: Engage in road and bridge construction
Produce sailboats made to customer specifications
Produce hollow blocks for sale to the public
Construct houses according to customer plans

explanation: Process costing is used for mass production of identical units, like hollow blocks, while job order costing would be used for the other options which involve unique, custom products.

text: The FIFO method of process costing differs from the average method in that the FIFO method

choices.text: Considers the stage of completion of beginning work in process inventory in computing equivalent units of production, but the average method does not
Does not consider the stage of completion of beginning work in process inventory in computing equivalent units of production, but the average method does
Is applicable only to those companies using the FIFO inventory pricing method, but the average method may be used with any inventory pricing method
Allocates costs based on whole units, but the average method uses equivalent units

explanation: The FIFO method specifically accounts for the completion status of beginning WIP inventory when calculating equivalent units, while the average method combines beginning and current period costs without considering the stage of completion.

text: The average and FIFO process costing methods differ in that the average method

choices.text: Can be used under any cost flow assumption
Is much more difficult to apply than the FIFO method
Requires that ending work in process inventory be stated in terms of equivalent units of production
Does not consider the degree of completion of beginning work in process inventory when computing equivalent units of production

explanation: The average method combines beginning and current period costs without considering the stage of completion of beginning WIP inventory, while FIFO does consider this factor.

text: Current periods cost per equivalent unit under FIFO process costing considers current period costs

choices.text: Only
Plus cost of beginning WIP
Less cost of beginning WIP
Plus cost of ending WIP

explanation: Under FIFO process costing, the cost per equivalent unit is calculated using only current period costs, as beginning WIP costs are accounted for separately.

text: Equivalent units of production are equal to the

choices.text: Units completed by a production department in the period
Number of units worked on during the period by a production department
Number of whole units that could have been completed if all work of the period had been used to produce whole units
Identifiable units existing at the end of the period in a production department

explanation: Equivalent units of production represent the number of complete units that could have been produced given the total work performed during the period, accounting for partially completed units.

text: In a process costing system using the weighted average method, cost per equivalent unit for a given cost component is found by dividing which of the following by EUP?

choices.text: Only current period cost
Current period cost plus the cost of beginning inventory
Current period cost less the cost of beginning inventory
Current period cost plus the cost of ending inventory

explanation: The weighted average method combines current period costs with beginning inventory costs when calculating the cost per equivalent unit.

text: In a cost of production report using process costing, transferred-in costs are similar to the

choices.text: Cost of material added at the beginning of production
Conversion cost added during the period
Cost transferred out to the next department
Cost included in beginning inventory

explanation: Transferred-in costs are similar to materials added at the beginning of production because they are both costs that are added at the start of a department's processing.

text: A continuous loss

choices.text: Occurs unevenly throughout a process
Never occurs during the production process
Always occurs at the same place in a production process
Occurs evenly throughout the production process

explanation: A continuous loss is one that occurs uniformly throughout the production process, as opposed to discrete losses which occur at specific points.

text: The method of neglect handles spoilage that is

choices.text: Discrete and abnormal
Discrete and normal
Continuous and abnormal
Continuous and normal

explanation: The method of neglect is used for normal continuous spoilage, where the cost of spoiled units is automatically absorbed by the good units produced.

text: The cost of normal discrete losses is

choices.text: Absorbed by all units past the inspection point on an equivalent unit basis
Absorbed by all units in ending inventory
Considered a period cost
Written off as a loss on an equivalent unit basis

explanation: Normal discrete losses are allocated to the good units that have passed the inspection point, as these units benefit from the production process that resulted in the spoilage.

text: The cost of abnormal continuous losses is

choices.text: Considered a product cost
Absorbed by all units in ending inventory and transferred out on an equivalent unit basis
Written off as a loss on an equivalent unit basis
Absorbed by all units past the inspection point

explanation: Abnormal continuous losses are treated as period costs and written off as losses, as they represent unexpected waste that should not be included in product costs.

text: Normal spoilage units resulting from a continuous process

choices.text: Are extended to the EUP schedule
Result in a higher unit cost for the good units produced
Result in a loss being incurred
Cause estimated overhead to increase

explanation: Normal spoilage costs are absorbed by the good units produced, which increases their unit cost since the total costs are spread over fewer good units.

text: If normal spoilage is detected at an inspection point within the process rather than at the end, the cost of that spoilage should be

choices.text: Included with the cost of the units sold during the period
Included with the cost of the units completed in that department during the period
Allocated to ending work in process units and units transferred out based on their relative values
Allocated to the good units that have passed the inspection point

explanation: When normal spoilage is detected at an inspection point, its cost should be allocated to the good units that have passed that point, as these units have benefited from the production process up to that stage.

text: Joint costs are useful for

choices.text: Setting the selling price of a product
Determining whether to continue producing an item
Evaluating management by means of a responsibility reporting system
Determining inventory cost for accounting purposes

explanation: Joint costs are primarily used for inventory valuation and financial reporting purposes, as they help allocate costs to products for balance sheet and income statement presentation.

text: This method of allocating joint manufacturing costs to main joint products allocates joint costs on the basis of estimated sales value at split off of a given joint product relative to the sales value at split off of total joint production?

choices.text: Market value at split-off approach
Hypothetical market value or approximated net realizable value approach
Average unit or production output method
Weighted average method

explanation: The market value at split-off approach allocates joint costs based on the relative sales values of products at the split-off point, which is where products become separately identifiable.

text: For products that need further processing, this method is more suitable because it takes into account the additional costs needed to further process and sell the joint products. Under this method of allocating manufacturing costs to main products, joint cost is allocated to products using the following the net realizable value ratio of the products

choices.text: Market value at split-off approach
Hypothetical market value or approximated net realizable value approach
Average unit or production output method
Weighted average method

explanation: The approximated net realizable value approach is most appropriate for products requiring further processing because it considers both the final selling price and the additional processing costs.

text: Approximated net realizable value for joint products is computed as

choices.text: Selling price at split-off minus further processing and disposal costs
Final selling price minus further processing and disposal costs
Selling price at split-off minus allocated joint processing costs
Final selling price minus a normal profit margin

explanation: The approximated net realizable value is calculated by taking the final selling price and subtracting all costs required to complete and sell the product, including further processing and disposal costs.

text: In a joint production process, a by-product is also described as

choices.text: A simultaneously produced product of relatively low value
A form of main product with controllable production proportions
Waste
Products of low value recovered at the end of a production process

explanation: A by-product is a secondary product that is produced along with the main product(s) in a joint production process, but has a relatively low sales value compared to the main products.

text: If the net realizable value of the by-product of a joint production process is significant, how shall it be accounted for?

choices.text: The net realizable value of the by-product shall be recorded as deduction from the total joint manufacturing cost thereby reducing the cost of the main products also known as replacement cost method
The net realizable value of the by-product shall be recorded as deduction from the net sales of the main product
The net realizable value of the by-product shall be recorded as deduction from the cost of sales of the main product
The net realizable value of the by-product shall be recorded as other income

explanation: When a by-product has significant value, its net realizable value is treated as a reduction of the joint costs, which effectively reduces the cost allocated to the main products.

text: The net realizable value approach is normally used when the NRV of the by-product is expected to be Insignificant Significant Insignificant Significant

choices.text: Yes Yes
No Yes
No No
Yes No

explanation: The net realizable value approach is typically used when the by-product has significant value, as it provides a more accurate allocation of costs between main products and by-products.

text: Just-in-time (JIT) inventory systems

choices.text: Result in a greater number of suppliers for each production process
Focus on a push type of production system
Can only be used with automated production processes
Result in inventories being either greatly reduced or eliminated

explanation: JIT inventory systems aim to minimize or eliminate inventory by having materials arrive just when they are needed in the production process, rather than maintaining large stockpiles.

text: It is a product costing system generally used in just-in-time inventory environment. This costing system delays the costing process until the production of goods is completed by eliminating the detailed tracking of cost throughout the production system and preparing journal entries only at trigger points

choices.text: Backflush costing
Standard costing
Normal costing
Traditional costing

explanation: Backflush costing is designed for JIT environments where it simplifies the accounting process by recording costs only at the end of the production process, rather than tracking costs throughout the production cycle.

text: An accounting system that collects financial and operating data on the basis of the underlying nature and extent of the cost drivers is

choices.text: Direct costing
Activity-based costing
Cycle-time costing
Variable costing

explanation: Activity-based costing (ABC) is a costing method that identifies activities in an organization and assigns the cost of each activity to all products and services according to the actual consumption by each.

text: Design of an ABC system requires

choices.text: That the job bid process be redesigned
That a cause-and-effect relationship exists between resource costs and individual activities
An adjustment to product mix
Both b and c

explanation: ABC system design requires establishing clear cause-and-effect relationships between activities and costs to ensure accurate cost allocation.

text: Of the following, which is the best reason for using activity-based costing?

choices.text: Keep better track of overhead costs
To more accurately assign overhead costs to cost pools so that these costs are better controlled
To better assign overhead costs to products
To assign indirect service overhead costs to direct overhead cost pools

explanation: The primary purpose of ABC is to provide more accurate product costing by better assigning overhead costs to products based on their actual consumption of activities.

text: An objective of activity-based management is to

choices.text: Eliminate the majority of centralized activities in an organization
Reduce or eliminate non-value-added activities incurred to make a product or provide a service
Institute responsibility accounting systems in decentralized organizations
All of the above

explanation: Activity-based management focuses on improving efficiency by identifying and eliminating non-value-added activities that don't contribute to customer value.

text: Activity-based management (ABM) is

choices.text: A costing system in which multiple overhead cost pools are allocated using bases that include one or more nonvolume-related factors
A base used to allocate the cost of a resource to the different activities using it
The use of information obtained from ABC to make improvements in the firm
A base used to allocate the cost of an activity to products and customers

explanation: ABM is the application of ABC information to improve business processes and make better decisions about products, services, and customers.

text: An _______________ method first traces costs to activities and then to products

choices.text: Direct costing
Absorption costing
Traditional costing
Activity-based costing

explanation: ABC first identifies activities and their costs, then traces these costs to products based on the products' consumption of activities.

text: An _______________ method first traces costs to a department and then to products

choices.text: Direct costing
Absorption costing
Traditional costing
Activity-based costing

explanation: Traditional costing systems first accumulate costs by department and then allocate these costs to products, typically using a single cost driver like direct labor hours.

text: A basic assumption of activity-based costing (ABC) is that

choices.text: All manufacturing costs vary directly with units of production
Products or services require the performance of activities, and activities consume resources
Only costs that respond to unit-level drivers are product costs
Only variable costs are included in activity-cost pools

explanation: ABC is based on the fundamental assumption that products consume activities, and activities consume resources, creating a chain of cost causation.

text: Which of the following is not typical of traditional costing systems?

choices.text: Use of a single predetermined overhead rate
Use of direct labor hours or direct labor cost to assign overhead
Assumption of correlation between direct labor and incurrence of overhead cost
Use of multiple cost drivers to allocate overhead

explanation: Traditional costing systems typically use a single cost driver (like direct labor hours) to allocate overhead, while ABC uses multiple cost drivers.

text: Traditional overhead allocations result in which of the following situations?

choices.text: Overhead costs are assigned as period costs to manufacturing operations
High-volume products are assigned too much overhead, and low-volume products are assigned too little overhead
Low-volume products are assigned too much, and high-volume products are assigned too little overhead
The resulting allocations cannot be used for financial reports

explanation: Traditional costing tends to overcost high-volume products and undercost low-volume products because it doesn't account for the complexity of activities required by different products.

text: Cost allocation bases in activity-based costing should be

choices.text: Cost drivers
Value-added activities
Activity centers
Processes

explanation: Cost drivers are the factors that cause costs to be incurred and are used as the basis for allocating costs in ABC systems.

text: A cost pool is

choices.text: All of the costs of a particular department
All costs in a group such as variable costs or discretionary fixed costs
All costs related to a product or product line
All costs that have the same driver

explanation: A cost pool is a grouping of individual costs that are allocated using the same cost driver.

text: Value-added activities

choices.text: Increase the worth of a product or service to customers
Involve resource usage and related costs that customers are willing to pay for
Are the activities of actually manufacturing a product or performing a service
All of the above

explanation: Value-added activities are those that enhance the product or service in ways that customers are willing to pay for, including manufacturing and service delivery activities.

text: Which of the following is a value-added activity?

choices.text: Inventory storage
Machining
Building maintenance
Bookkeeping

explanation: Machining is a value-added activity because it directly transforms materials into finished products that customers are willing to pay for.

text: Which of the following is a value-added activity?

choices.text: Inventory control
Inspections
Packaging
Repair of machines

explanation: Packaging is a value-added activity because it protects the product and makes it ready for customer use, adding value that customers are willing to pay for.

text: Which of the following is a non-value-added activity?

choices.text: Inventory control
Machining
Assembly
Painting

explanation: Inventory control is a non-value-added activity because it doesn't directly contribute to the product's value from the customer's perspective.

text: Which of the following is a non-value-added activity?

choices.text: Painting
Finishing
Packaging
Building maintenance

explanation: Building maintenance is a non-value-added activity as it doesn't directly contribute to the product's value from the customer's perspective.

text: The cost of processing customer complaints is an

choices.text: Appraisal cost
External failure cost
Internal failure cost
Prevention cost

explanation: Processing customer complaints is an external failure cost because it occurs after the product has reached the customer and represents a failure to meet customer expectations.

text: Worker training is an

choices.text: Appraisal cost
External failure cost
Internal failure cost
Prevention cost

explanation: Worker training is a prevention cost because it helps prevent quality problems from occurring in the first place.

text: ____________ are those performed each time a unit is produced or sold

choices.text: Batch-level activities
Facility-sustaining activities
Sustaining activities
Unit-level activities

explanation: Unit-level activities are performed for each individual unit of product or service.

text: Costs that are common to many different activities within an organization are known as ____________ costs

choices.text: Product-or process-level
Organizational level
Batch-level
Unit-level

explanation: Organizational-level costs are those that support the entire organization and are common to many different activities.

text: ____________ are those that a company performs when it makes a group of units

choices.text: Batch-level activities
Facility-sustaining activities
Sustaining activities
Unit-level activities

explanation: Batch-level activities are performed for each batch or group of units, regardless of the number of units in the batch.

text: ____________ relate to an entire plant as a whole

choices.text: Batch-level activities
Facility-sustaining activities
Sustaining activities
Unit-level activities

explanation: Facility-sustaining activities support the entire plant or facility and are not related to specific products or batches.

text: Examples of activities at the unit level of costs include

choices.text: Cutting, painting, and packaging
Scheduling, setting up, and moving
Designing, changing, and advertising
Heating, lighting, and security

explanation: Unit-level activities are performed for each individual unit and include direct manufacturing activities like cutting, painting, and packaging.

text: Examples of activities at the product level of costs include

choices.text: Cutting, painting, and packaging
Scheduling, setting up, and moving
Designing, changing, and advertising
Heating, lighting, and security

explanation: Product-level activities support specific product lines and include activities like product design, engineering changes, and product-specific advertising.

text: Examples of activities at the batch level of costs include

choices.text: Cutting, painting, and packaging
Scheduling, setting up, and moving
Designing, changing, and advertising
Heating, lighting, and security

explanation: Batch-level activities are performed for each batch of products and include activities like production scheduling, machine setup, and material movement.

text: Examples of activities at the plant level of costs include

choices.text: Cutting, painting, and packaging
Scheduling, setting up, and moving
Designing, changing, and advertising
Heating, lighting, and security

explanation: Plant-level activities support the entire facility and include activities like building maintenance, utilities, and security services.

text: A foreign currency transaction includes which of the following?

choices.text: Purchase and sale of goods whose price is denominated in a foreign currency
Borrowing and lending of funds when the amounts payable or receivable are denominated in a foreign currency
Incurrence and settlement of liabilities denominated in foreign currency
All of the above

explanation: Foreign currency transactions include all transactions denominated in a currency other than the entity's functional currency, including purchases, sales, borrowing, lending, and liability transactions.

text: What is a company's functional currency?

choices.text: The currency of the primary economic environment in which it operates
The currency of the country where it has its headquarters
The currency in which it prepares its financial statements
The reporting currency of its parent for a subsidiary

explanation: The functional currency is the currency of the primary economic environment in which the entity operates, not necessarily the currency of the country where it is headquartered or the currency used for reporting.

text: In accounting, the term translation refers to

choices.text: The calculation of gains or losses from hedging transactions
The calculation of exchange rate gains or losses on individual transactions in foreign currencies
The procedure required to identify a company's functional currency
A procedure to prepare a foreign subsidiary's financial statements for consolidation

explanation: Translation is the process of converting a foreign subsidiary's financial statements from its functional currency to the parent company's reporting currency for consolidation purposes.

text: For a foreign subsidiary that uses the US dollar as its functional currency, what translation method is required?

choices.text: Current/Noncurrent Method
Monetary/Nonmonetary Method
Current Rate Method
Temporal Method

explanation: When a foreign subsidiary uses the US dollar as its functional currency, the temporal method is required for translation, as it maintains the measurement basis of the original transactions.

text: According to PAS 21, which method is usually required for translating a foreign subsidiary's financial statements into the parent's reporting currency?

choices.text: The temporal method
The current rate method
The current/noncurrent method
The monetary/nonmonetary method

explanation: PAS 21 generally requires the current rate method for translating foreign subsidiary financial statements when the subsidiary's functional currency is different from the parent's reporting currency.

text: Which accounts are remeasured using current exchange rates?

choices.text: All revenues and expenses
All assets and liabilities
All monetary assets and liabilities
All current assets and liabilities

explanation: Under the temporal method, monetary assets and liabilities are remeasured using current exchange rates, while nonmonetary items are remeasured using historical rates.

text: In translating a foreign subsidiary's financial statements, which exchange rate does the current method require for the subsidiary's assets and liabilities?

choices.text: The exchange rate in effect when each asset or liability was acquired
The average exchange rate for the current year
A calculated exchange rate based on market value
The exchange rate in effect as of the balance sheet date

explanation: The current rate method requires using the exchange rate in effect at the balance sheet date for translating assets and liabilities.

text: The translation adjustment from translating a foreign subsidiary's financial statements should be shown as

choices.text: An asset or liability depending on the balance on the consolidated balance sheet
A revenue or expense depending on the balance on the consolidated income statement
A component of stockholders' equity on the consolidated balance sheet
A component of cash flows from financing activities on the consolidated statement of cash flows

explanation: Translation adjustments are reported as a separate component of stockholders' equity in the consolidated balance sheet, not as income or expense.

text: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: Foreign currency is a currency other than the functional currency of the entity
Functional currency is the currency of the primary economic environment in which the entity operates
An entity is required to present the financial statements using the functional currency
Presentation currency is the currency in which the financial statements are presented

explanation: While an entity must measure its financial statements in its functional currency, it is not required to present them in that currency. The presentation currency can be different from the functional currency.

text: How is the disposition of the translated gain or loss reported on the parent company's financial statements?

choices.text: Net income/loss on the income statement
Cumulative translation adjustment as a deferred asset
Cumulative translation adjustment as a deferred liability
Other comprehensive income

explanation: According to PAS 21, upon disposition of a foreign operation, the foreign currency translation gain or loss in other comprehensive income shall be subsequently reclassified into profit or loss.

text: It is a financial instrument that derives its value from an underlying such as a share price, exchange rate or interest rate

choices.text: Derivative
Financial asset
Financial liability
Equity instrument

explanation: A derivative is a financial instrument whose value is derived from an underlying asset, index, or reference rate, such as share prices, exchange rates, or interest rates.

text: The basic purpose of derivative financial instruments is to manage some kind of risk such as all of the following, except

choices.text: Currency fluctuation
Interest rate variation
Stock price movement
Uncollectibility of accounts receivable

explanation: Derivatives are used to manage market risks like currency fluctuations, interest rate variations, and stock price movements, but not credit risks like uncollectible accounts.

text: All of the following are characteristics of a derivative, except

choices.text: It is settled at a future date
It requires no initial investment or an initial small net investment
Its value changes in response to the change in a specified underlying
It is acquired for the purpose of generating a profit from short-term fluctuations

explanation: While derivatives can be used for speculation, this is not a defining characteristic. The key characteristics are future settlement, minimal initial investment, and value changes based on an underlying.

text: Entities that attempt to exploit inefficiencies in various derivative markets by attempting to lock in profits by simultaneously entering into transactions in two or more markets are called

choices.text: Arbitrageurs
Gamblers
Hedgers
Speculators

explanation: Arbitrageurs are market participants who attempt to profit from price differences in different markets by simultaneously buying and selling the same or similar instruments.

text: Any financial or physical variable that has either observable changes or objectively verifiable changes qualifies as

choices.text: Notional amount
Hedge
Financial instrument
Underlying

explanation: An underlying is any variable (financial or physical) that has observable or objectively verifiable changes, which is used to determine the value of a derivative instrument.

text: Which of the following is an underlying?

choices.text: A credit rating
A security price
An average daily temperature
All of these could be underlyings

explanation: All of these variables (credit rating, security price, and temperature) can serve as underlyings for derivative instruments as they have observable or verifiable changes.

text: An example of a notional amount is

choices.text: Currency swap
Interest rate
Number of barrels of oil
Stock price

explanation: The notional amount is the quantity of the underlying item in a derivative contract, such as the number of barrels of oil in an oil futures contract.

text: Which of the following instruments is not considered a derivative financial instrument?

choices.text: Currency futures
Stock index option
Bank certificate of deposit
Interest rate swap

explanation: A bank certificate of deposit is a traditional financial instrument, not a derivative. The other options (futures, options, and swaps) are all types of derivatives.

text: It is a commitment to purchase a specified commodity on a future date at a specified price through a futures exchange market

choices.text: Forward contract
Futures contract
Call option
Put option

explanation: A futures contract is a standardized agreement to buy or sell a specific commodity at a predetermined price on a future date, traded on an organized exchange.

text: A call option is

choices.text: Not recognized in the financial statements but only disclosed
Recognized and classified as current asset
Recognized and classified as noncurrent asset
Recognized as expense immediately

explanation: A call option is recognized as a current asset in the financial statements, as it represents a right to purchase an asset at a specified price within a short period.

text: Which of the following provides the holder the right to sell at an exercise or strike price anytime during a specified period, where a gain accrues to the holder as the market price of the underlying falls below the strike price?

choices.text: Forward contract
Put option
Swaption
Call option

explanation: A put option gives the holder the right to sell the underlying asset at a specified price (strike price) during a specific period, with gains occurring when the market price falls below the strike price.

text: Which is incorrect concerning an option?

choices.text: A call option is the right to purchase an asset at a specified price during a definite period at some future time
A put option is the right to sell an asset at a specified price during a definite period at some future time
An option is a right and not an obligation to purchase or sell an asset
An option requires no initial payment

explanation: Options do require an initial payment (premium) to be made by the buyer to the seller in exchange for the right to buy or sell the underlying asset.

text: It is an agreement whereby one party will receive a swap payment from another party if the interest rate is more than the underlying interest rate and will make a swap payment to the other party if the interest rate is lower than the underlying interest rate

choices.text: Receive fixed interest rate swap
Receive variable, pay interest rate swap
Receive fixed, pay variable interest rate swap
Receive variable interest rate swap

explanation: In a receive fixed, pay variable interest rate swap, one party receives fixed interest payments and makes variable interest payments based on the underlying interest rate.

text: A derivative may be

choices.text: An asset account
A liability account
An owner's equity account
Either an asset or a liability account

explanation: A derivative can be either an asset or a liability depending on whether it has a positive or negative fair value at the reporting date.

text: Derivatives are measured at

choices.text: Fair value
Cost
Fair value less cost to sell
Higher between fair value and cost

explanation: Derivatives are always measured at fair value, with changes in fair value recognized in profit or loss unless the derivative is designated as a hedging instrument.

text: Change in fair value of a derivative financial instrument that is determined to be an effective cash flow hedge shall

choices.text: Be recognized in profit or loss
Be recognized directly in equity
Be included in retained earnings
Not be recognized

explanation: For an effective cash flow hedge, the change in fair value of the hedging instrument is recognized directly in equity (other comprehensive income) until the hedged item affects profit or loss.

text: PFRS 3 defines it as a transaction or event in which an acquirer obtains control of one or more businesses

choices.text: Business combination
Consolidation
Merger
Acquisition of net assets

explanation: According to PFRS 3, a business combination is defined as a transaction or event in which an acquirer obtains control of one or more businesses.

text: A business combination whereby the company taking over the properties of other companies retains its identity and continues operations as a larger unit and the other companies are dissolved is known as a

choices.text: Consolidation
Merger
Pooling of interests
Quasi-reorganization

explanation: A merger occurs when one company (the surviving company) takes over the properties of other companies, retains its identity, and continues operations as a larger unit, while the other companies are dissolved.

text: A business combination in which a new corporation is created, and two or more existing corporations are combined into the newly created corporation is called a

choices.text: Merger
Purchase transaction
Pooling-of-interests
Consolidation

explanation: A consolidation is a business combination where a new corporation is created to combine two or more existing corporations, with the original corporations being dissolved.

text: Under PFRS 3, how should an entity acquirer account for each business combination?

choices.text: Pooling of interest method
Proportionate consolidation method
Acquisition method
Equity method

explanation: PFRS 3 requires the acquisition method for accounting for business combinations, which involves identifying the acquirer, determining the acquisition date, and measuring the consideration transferred.

text: It refers to the date on which the acquirer obtains control of the acquiree

choices.text: Business combination date
Acquisition date
Control date
Consolidation date

explanation: The acquisition date is the date on which the acquirer obtains control of the acquiree, which is when the business combination is consummated.

text: The acquisition method of accounting for a business combination requires all of the following, except

choices.text: Identifying the acquirer
Determining the acquisition date
Recognizing and measuring the identifiable assets acquired, the liabilities assumed and the noncontrolling interest in the acquiree at carrying amount
Recognizing goodwill or gain from bargain purchase

explanation: Under the acquisition method, identifiable assets and liabilities are measured at fair value, not carrying amount, and noncontrolling interest is measured at fair value or proportionate share of net assets.

text: In a business combination, goodwill is measured as the excess of

choices.text: The consideration transferred over the identifiable net assets acquired
The total of the consideration transferred and the amount of any non-controlling interest in the acquiree over the identifiable assets acquired
The total of the consideration received and the fair value of the previously held interest in the acquiree over the identifiable net assets acquired

The total of the consideration transferred, the amount of any non-controlling interest in the acquiree and the fair value of previously held interest in the acquiree over the identifiable net assets acquired

explanation: Goodwill is measured as the excess of the total consideration (including non-controlling interest and previously held interest) over the fair value of identifiable net assets acquired.

text: Under PFRS 10, an investor controls an investee if the investor has all of the following, except

choices.text: The power over the investee
Exposure or rights to variable returns from the involvement with the investee
The ability to use the power over the investee to affect the amount of the investor's returns
All of these indicate control

explanation: All of these elements (power, returns, and ability to affect returns) are required for control under PFRS 10. The question asks for the exception, but there is none as all elements are necessary.

text: Control is presumed to exist when the parent owns directly or indirectly through subsidiaries

choices.text: More than half of the equity of the entity
More than half of the ordinary shares of an entity
More than half of the preference and ordinary shares of an entity
More than half of the voting power of an entity

explanation: Control is presumed to exist when the parent owns more than half of the voting power of an entity, as this gives the parent the power to govern the financial and operating policies of the entity.

text: Which of the following statements is/are correct according to PFRS 10?

choices.text: Consolidated financial statements are the financial statements of a group in which the assets, liabilities, equity, income, expenses and cash flows of the parent and its subsidiaries are presented as those of a single economic entity
Separate financial statements are the financial statements by a parent in which the investments are accounted for on the basis of the direct equity interest

Noncontrolling interest is that portion of the profit or loss and net assets of a subsidiary attributable to equity interests that are not owned directly or indirectly through subsidiaries by the parent
All of the above

explanation: All statements are correct according to PFRS 10, which defines consolidated financial statements, separate financial statements, and noncontrolling interest in these terms.

text: How shall the parent corporation present the Noncontrolling Interest (NCI) in the Consolidated Statement of Financial Position?

choices.text: It shall be presented within Consolidated Stockholders' Equity, separately from the equity of the owners of the parent
It shall be presented as non-current liability
It shall be presented as non-current assets
It shall be presented as contra-equity account like treasury shares and subscription receivable

explanation: Noncontrolling interest represents the equity in a subsidiary not attributable to the parent and should be presented as a separate component of equity in the consolidated financial statements.

text: It is characterized by a contractual arrangement whereby two or more parties have joint control of the arrangement

choices.text: Joint arrangement
Joint operation
Joint venture
Jointly controlled asset

explanation: A joint arrangement is defined by PFRS 11 as an arrangement of which two or more parties have joint control, established through a contractual agreement.

text: It is contractually agreed sharing of control of an arrangement which exists only when decisions about relevant activities required unanimous consent of the parties sharing control

choices.text: Control
Significant influence
Joint control
Solidary control

explanation: Joint control is the contractually agreed sharing of control of an arrangement, which exists only when decisions about the relevant activities require the unanimous consent of the parties sharing control.

text: It is a type of joint arrangement whereby the parties that have joint control of the arrangement have right to the total assets and obligations for the total liabilities relating to the arrangement

choices.text: Joint venture
Jointly controlled asset
Joint operation
Joint business

explanation: A joint operation is a joint arrangement whereby the parties that have joint control of the arrangement have rights to the assets and obligations for the liabilities relating to the arrangement.

text: It is a type of joint arrangement whereby the parties that have joint control of the arrangement have rights to the net assets of the arrangement

choices.text: Joint venture
Jointly controlled asset
Joint operation
Joint business

explanation: A joint venture is a joint arrangement whereby the parties that have joint control of the arrangement have rights to the net assets of the arrangement.

text: What is the classification of the joint arrangement when the assets and liabilities relating to the arrangement are held by a separate vehicle or when the arrangement is established with a separate vehicle?

choices.text: It shall be classified as joint venture
It shall be classified as joint operation
Neither joint venture nor joint operation
It can be either a joint operation or joint venture depending on the legal form of the separate vehicle, terms of the contractual arrangement or other relevant facts and circumstances

explanation: The classification of a joint arrangement with a separate vehicle depends on the legal form of the vehicle, the terms of the contractual arrangement, and other relevant facts and circumstances.

text: Under PFRS 11, how shall the joint venturer account for its Investment in Joint Venture?

choices.text: Equity method
Cost method
Fair value method under IFRS 9
Proportionate consolidation

explanation: Under PFRS 11, a joint venturer shall account for its investment in a joint venture using the equity method as prescribed in PAS 28.

text: Under PFRS 11, how shall the joint operator account for its interest in a joint operation?

choices.text: The joint operator shall account for its interest under Equity Method
The joint operator shall account for its interest under Cost Method
The joint operator shall account for its interest using proportionate consolidation

The joint operator shall account for its interest by recognizing its assets, liabilities, revenues, expenses and shares in the jointly controlled assets, jointly incurred liabilities, jointly earned revenue and jointly incurred expenses in accordance with the contractual agreement

explanation: A joint operator shall account for its interest in a joint operation by recognizing its share of the assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses in accordance with the contractual arrangement.

text: It encompasses the processes of analyzing, recording, classifying, summarizing and communicating all transactions involving the receipt and disposition of government funds and property, interpreting the results thereof

choices.text: Government auditing
Government reporting
Government accounting
Government analyzing
