explanation: Government accounting involves the systematic process of recording, classifying, summarizing, and communicating all transactions involving government funds and property.

text: What is the title of the revised government accounting system for national government agencies which will be effective January 1, 2016?

choices.text: Government Accounting Manual (GAM)
New Government Accounting System (NGAS)
Philippine Government Accounting System (PGAS)
National Government Accounting Manual (NGAM)

explanation: The Government Accounting Manual (GAM) is the revised accounting system for national government agencies effective January 1, 2016.

text: Which government body keeps the general account of government, promulgates accounting rules and regulation, and submits to the President and Congress an annual financial report of the government?

choices.text: Commission on Audit
Department of Budget and Management
Bureau of Treasury
Department of Finance

explanation: The Commission on Audit (COA) is responsible for keeping the general account of government, promulgating accounting rules, and submitting annual financial reports.

text: Which is responsible for the design, preparation and approval of accounting systems of government agencies?

choices.text: Department of Budget and Management
Bureau of Treasury
Commission on Audit
The government agency concerned

explanation: The Commission on Audit (COA) is responsible for the design, preparation, and approval of accounting systems of government agencies.

text: No money shall be paid out of the National Treasury except in pursuance of

choices.text: Appropriation
Allotment
Obligation
Special executive order

explanation: The Constitution provides that no money shall be paid out of the National Treasury except in pursuance of an appropriation made by law.

text: It is the authorization from the Department of Budget and Management to any agency to incur obligation up to a specified amount that must be within the legislative appropriation

choices.text: Obligation
Appropriation
Allotment
Fund release

explanation: An allotment is the authorization from the DBM to an agency to incur obligations up to a specified amount within the legislative appropriation.

text: What is the role of the Bureau of Treasury in relation to government accounting responsibility?

choices.text: To receive and keep national funds and manage or control disbursements thereof
To design, prepare, and approve the accounting systems of government agencies
To keep the general accounts of the national government
To prepare the annual financial report of the national government, its instrumentalities and government-owned or controlled corporations

explanation: The Bureau of Treasury is responsible for receiving, keeping, and managing national funds and controlling their disbursement.

text: It refers to the first step in the government budgetary process wherein the President, through the assistance of the Department of Budget and Management, shall prepare and submit to the Congress within 30 days from the opening of regular session of Congress a budget of expenditures and sources of financing, including receipts from existing and proposed revenue measures

choices.text: Budget Preparation
Budget Legislation
Budget Execution
Budget Accountability

explanation: Budget preparation is the first step in the government budgetary process, involving the preparation and submission of the budget by the President.

text: It refers to the second step in the government budgetary process which involves the enactment by the Congress of the General Appropriation Act (GAA) based on the budget submitted by the President which cannot be increased by the Congress. The initiative for the enactment of the appropriation law shall come from the House of Representatives

choices.text: Budget Preparation
Budget Legislation
Budget Execution
Budget Accountability

explanation: Budget legislation is the second step, involving the enactment of the General Appropriation Act by Congress.

text: It refers to the third step in the government budgetary process which involves the implementation of the general appropriation act which includes the release of revenue allotment under the supervision of Department of Budget and Management

choices.text: Budget Preparation
Budget Legislation
Budget Execution
Budget Accountability

explanation: Budget execution is the third step, involving the implementation of the General Appropriation Act and the release of allotments.

text: It refers to the final step in the government budgetary process which involves the submission of property documentary reports by responsible officer, liquidation of expenditures and audit conducted by Commission on Audit to ensure the public funds are spent in accordance with the appropriation act

choices.text: Budget Preparation
Budget Legislation
Budget Execution
Budget Accountability

explanation: Budget accountability is the final step, involving reporting, liquidation, and audit to ensure proper use of public funds.

text: The books of accounts of National Government Agencies under the GAM shall consist of the following, except

choices.text: General Journal
Cash Receipts Journal
Cash Disbursement Journal
Check Disbursements Journal e. General Ledgers f. Subsidiary Ledgers g. Regular Agency and National Government Books

explanation: The books of accounts under the GAM do not include "Regular Agency and National Government Books" as a specific book.

text: The registries of National Government Agencies under the GAM shall consist of the following, except

choices.text: Registries of Revenue and Other Receipts (RROR)
Registry of Appropriation and Allotments (RAPAL)
Registries of Allotments, Obligations and Disbursements (RAOD)
Registries of Budget, Utilization and Disbursements (RBUD) e. Registries of Priority Development Assistant Program (RPDAP)

explanation: RPDAP is not a required registry under the GAM for National Government Agencies.

text: The following are the classifications of different RAPAL, RAOD and RBUD, except

choices.text: RAPAL/RAOD/RBUD Personal Services
RAPAL/RAOD/RBUD Maintenance and Other Operating Expenses
RAPAL/RAOD/RBUD Financial Expenses
RAPAL/RAOD/RBUD Capital Outlays e. RAPAL/RAOD/RBUD Noncash Expenses

explanation: Noncash expenses are not a classification for RAPAL, RAOD, or RBUD.

text: On January 1, 2020, the collecting officer of Bureau of Customs collected P450,000 import duties plus fines of P50,000 on the goods of an importer. On February 1, 2020, the Bureau of Customs remitted the P500,000 to the Bureau of Treasury. Question 1: What is the journal entry to record the collecting of the import duties and fines?

choices.text: Debit Cash - Treasury/Agency Deposit, Regular P500,000 and Credit Cash - Collecting Officer P500,000
Debit Cash - Collecting Officer P500,000 and Credit Import Duties P450,000 and Fines/Penalties P50,000
Debit Cash - Treasury/Agency Deposit, Regular P500,000 and Credit Import Duties P450,000 and Fines/Penalties P50,000
None of the above

explanation: The correct entry records the collection by the collecting officer, recognizing the cash received and the corresponding revenue accounts. Question 2: Using the same data, but assuming the importer directly deposited the P450,000 import duties and P50,000 fines through Authorized Agent Banks instead of collection by a customer collecting officer, what is the journal entry to record the collection/remittance of import duties to Bureau of Treasury? a. Debit Cash - Treasury/Agency Deposit, Regular P500,000 and Credit Cash - Collecting Officer P500,000 b. Debit Cash - Treasury/Agency Deposit, Regular P500,000 and Credit Import Duties P450,000 and Fines/Penalties P50,000 c. Debit Cash - Collecting Officer P500,000 and Credit Import Duties P450,000 and Fines/Penalties P50,000 d. None of the above Answer:  b. Debit Cash - Treasury/Agency Deposit, Regular P500,000 and Credit Import Duties P450,000 and Fines/Penalties P50,000 Explanation: When the importer deposits directly through the bank, the agency recognizes the cash in the Treasury/Agency Deposit and credits the revenue accounts.

text: On December 31, 2019, the Department of Finance billed its lessee on one of its buildings in the amount of P100,000. On January 31, 2020, the Department of Finance collected all of the accounts receivable. On February 28, 2020, the Department of Finance remitted the entire collected amount to the Bureau of Treasury. What is the journal entry to record the remittance by the Department of Finance to the Bureau of Treasury?

choices.text: Debit Accounts Receivable P100,000 and Credit Rent Income P100,000
Debit Cash - Collecting Officers P100,000 and Credit Accounts Receivable P100,000
Debit Cash - Treasury/Agency Deposit, Regular P100,000 and Credit Cash - Collecting Officer P100,000
Debit Accounts Receivable P100,000 and Credit Retained Earnings P100,000

explanation: The correct entry records the remittance of collected funds from the collecting officer to the Treasury/Agency Deposit.

text: Department of Health (DOH) received Notice of Cash Allocation in the amount of P200,000 from Department of Budget and Management. DOH made total cash disbursements in the amount of P195,000. What is the journal entry to recognize reversion of unused Notice of Cash Allocation by DOH in its books?

choices.text: Debit Expenses P5,000 and credit Cash - MDS, Regular P5,000
Debit Investment P5,000 and credit Cash - MDS, Regular P5,000
Debit Retained Earnings P5,000 and credit Cash - MDS, Regular P5,000
Debit Subsidy from National Government P5,000 and credit Cash - MDS, Regular P5,000

explanation: The reversion of unused NCA is recognized by debiting Subsidy from National Government and crediting Cash - MDS, Regular.

text: The Bureau of Treasury received P100,000 cash remittance from Department of Agrarian Reform (DAR) from its miscellaneous income. What is the journal entry of the Bureau of Treasury in its accounting books to record the receipt of cash remittance from the income of a national government agency?

choices.text: Debit Cash in Bank, Local Bank P100,000 and Credit Miscellaneous Income of DA P100,000
Debit Cash in Bank, Local Bank P100,000 and Credit Savings of DA, Regular P100,000
Debit Cash in Bank, Local Bank P100,000 and Credit Cash - Treasury/Agency Deposit, Regular P100,000
Debit Cash in Bank, Local Bank P100,000 and Credit Cash - Collecting Officer, DA P100,000

explanation: The Bureau of Treasury records the receipt of cash remittance from a national government agency by debiting Cash in Bank and crediting the Treasury/Agency Deposit account.
